Do not force it (then there will be a lot of bubbles in the tube), take your time, let the saliva flow into the tube calmly.

description: The Sally-Ann Task is aimed to measure the child's ability for Theory of Mind by asking them in which basket they think Sally will look for her ball,after Anne moved the ball from one basket into another while Sally was away.
reference: Baron-Cohen, S., Tager-Flusberg, H., & Cohen, D. (1993). Understanding other minds: perspectives from autism.Oxford: Oxford University Press.

description: The School Questionnaire consists of 11 items about school-going of the children,e.g.,which grade,type of school,etc.
The Secure Base Script Task (SBS) is aimed to measure one's secure base script/attachment representations by giving the participant a list of words with which they have to create a coherent story.
scoring:
Parents’ narratives were audio-recorded and subsequently transcribed. The transcripts were scored on a 7-point rating scale to summarize the amount of parental use of elements of a secure base script. Narratives that contained extensive secure base script 
with detailed elaborations received the highest scores (6-7), Narratives that contained elements of the secure base script but fell short in elaboration received moderately high scores (4-5), narratives that were event-focused and contained no evidence of the secure base script received a moderately low score (3), narratives with unusual or atypical content as well as narratives that seem disjointed received the lowest scores (1-2). For each narrative we averaged the scores assigned by the two coders. Scores of the three stories  were averaged into an overall score indicating parental knowledge of the secure base script.
instruction: This task is used to look at how people differ in the way they tell a story. In a bit, I will show you 4 of these cards with rows of words. We would like for you to use these word to create a story. You may use these words to make up a story. On this first card you see the title of the story and 3 rows of words. If you run down the rows of words from top to bottom you can discover the plot of the intended story. For example, the first card is about a trip to the park. The cards are meant to be a brief outline of the story. I would like to ask you to use the card as a starting point to tell the best possible story about <title card>. You don't have to use all the words if you don't want to and you can change the order of the words or the words themselves. The most important thing is that you come up with the best story you can tell. The length of each story should be about one page of written text, so please provide as much information and detail as you can think of. I will give you 2 minutes each time to look at the words and prepare a story. When you are ready to tell your story, you can tell me and start telling the story. If you don't completely know your storyline anymore, feel free to stop in between and take time to think. If you want to restart your story, that's no problem. You may now start creating the story with the first card.

description: The Self-Concept Tasked is aimed to measure a child's self-concept by asking them whether certain negative and positive traits fit them.

The Sensitive Discipline - Do task is aimed to measure parental sensitivity and discipline by observing parent-child interaction when the parent has to instruct the child to do something (e.g., clean up toys).
scoring: The task was filmed by a research assistant and later coded from the videos by separate teams of coders. The interactions were coded using the revised Erickson7-point rating scale for supportive presence (1 =  completely failing to be supportive, 7 = skillfully providing support. It was further coded using the revised Erickson 5-point scale for physical interference (1 = the parent does not interfere physically, 5 = the parent often interferes physically), harshness (0 = no, 1 = yes), and verbal overreaction and laxness of the parent (1 = none to 5 = continuously).
instruction: [Once the Don't task and freeplay period are over, the researcher will again give the parent a card.] "Your child should clean up the toys now. You can help a little bit if you want, but your child should do as much as possible themselves. You may now ask your child to start tidying up."

description: The Sensitive Discipline - Do/Don't combined task is aimed to measure parental sensitivity and discipline by observing parent-child interaction when the parent has to instruct the child to do something (e.g.,clean up toys; Do) and where the parent has to forbid the child to do something (e.g.,do not touch the toys while the parent plays with them; Don't).
scoring: The task was filmed by a research assistant and later coded from the videos by separate teams of coders. The interactions were coded using the revised Erickson7-point rating scale for supportive presence (1 =  completely failing to be supportive, 7 = skillfully providing support. It was further coded using the revised Erickson 5-point scale for physical interference (1 = the parent does not interfere physically, 5 = the parent often interferes physically), harshness (0 = no, 1 = yes), and verbal overreaction and laxness of the parent (1 = none to 5 = continuously).
instruction:
During Early Childhood Cohort, wave 5 & Middle Childhood Cohort, wave 1:
[On the screen:] In a minute I'll give bring over a tray with beads. Could you ask your child to sort all the beads by color? In the meantime, you can watch a video on the laptop, but you child should not be watching the video with you. Try to make sure your child keeps sorting the beads, just as you would normally do. You can ask your child to start sorting now. 

During Early Childhood Cohort, wave 6 & Middle Childhood Cohort, wave 2:
[On the screen:] In a minute I'll bring over a tray with elastic bands. Could you ask your child to sort all the elastic bands by color? In the meantime, you can watch a video on the laptop, but you child should not be watching the video with you. Try to make sure your child keeps sorting the elastic bands, just as you would normally do. You can ask your child to start sorting now. 

During Middle Childhood Cohort, wave 3: 
[On the screen:] In a minute, I'll bring over some writing exercises. Could you ask your child to do the writing exercises as neatly as possible? In the mean time, you can watch a video on the laptop, but your child should not be watching the video with you. Try to make sure your child keeps writing, just as you would normally do. You can ask your child to start writing as soon as I have left the room.

description: The Sensitive Discipline - Don't task is aimed to measure parental sensitivity and discipline by observing parent-child interaction in which the parent has to forbid the child to do something (e.g., do not touch the toys while the parent plays with them).
scoring: The task was filmed by a research assistant and later coded from the videos by separate teams of coders. The interactions were coded using the revised Erickson7-point rating scale for supportive presence (1 =  completely failing to be supportive, 7 = skillfully providing support. It was further coded using the revised Erickson 5-point scale for physical interference (1 = the parent does not interfere physically, 5 = the parent often interferes physically), harshness (0 = no, 1 = yes), and verbal overreaction and laxness of the parent (1 = none to 5 = continuously).
instruction: [Researcher enters room with bag of fun toys and gives a card to the primary parent]. "I'll give you a bag with some toys in a minute. We would like you to take the toys out of the bag, but your child should not touch the toys for a while. Don't start playing with other toys either. This is an assignment to see how different children react to this. After 2 minutes I will give you a signal by knocking on the window and you can play with one toy together. " [Researcher leaves the room, but If parent starts playing with all toys and/or lets child play with all toys, researcher comes into the room to tell them they can only play with the one toy.]

description: The Sensitivity - Etch-a-Sketch task is aimed to measure parental sensitvity by observing parent-child interaction during the playing of the Etch-a-Sketch game. The Etch-A-Sketch task is a cooperative learning challenge task that requires a parent to work together with their child in order to succeed. The parent and child are given one Etch-A-Sketch board and are instructed to use the board to copy a series of three designs that increase in complexity. The parent and child must work together as one controls the left knob (draws only horizontal lines) and one controls the right knob (draws only vertical lines). The parent and child are allowed a maximum of 5 minutes to complete each design, and participants are told that their accuracy on completing or copying the designs will be checked by the experimenter.
scoring: The task was filmed by a research assistant and later coded from the videos by separate teams of coders). The interactions were coded using the revised Erickson7-point rating scale for supportive presence (1 =  completely failing to be supportive, 7 = skillfully providing support). It was further coded using the revised Erickson 7-point rating scale for intrusiveness (1 =  nonintrusive, 7 _x0002_= highly intrusive).
instruction: The aim of this game is to create a picture together. You are supposed to operate two buttons per person. One of you operates the brown buttons and one of you the white buttons. With brown you can draw the line up or down. With white you can draw the line to the left or to the right. You can choose who controls which buttons. By pressing two buttons at the same time, you can make a slanted line. You can start drawing the castle, when you are done you can continue with the next drawings. When you are done with the first drawing you can click on the button “empty” so that you can make a seahorse and then a geometric figure. The drawings are saved automatically. If you have already completed all three drawings before I get back, you may redraw a drawing. Have fun!

description: The Sensitivity - Family game task is aimed to measure parental sensitivity  by observing parent-child interaction during the playing of a family game.
The Sensitivity - Free play task is aimed to measure parental sensitivity by observing parent-child interaction during free play without instructions.
scoring: The task was filmed by a research assistant and later coded from the videos by separate teams of coders. The interactions were coded using the revised Erickson7-point rating scale for supportive presence (1 =  completely failing to be supportive, 7 = skillfully providing support. It was further coded using the revised Erickson 7-point rating scale for intrusiveness (1 =  nonintrusive, 7 _x0002_= highly intrusive).
instruction: [Researcher brings extra toys into the room]: "Now you can play with everything." [After 8 minutes reseacher comes back].

description: The Sensorimotor Synchronization Task is aimed to assess the child's rhythmic coordination of perception and action by instructing the child to compare rhythms and judge whether sounds are in sync with a given rhythm.
The Skin Conductance - Cheating Task measures skin conductance during the Cheating Task, in which the child is given an opportunity to cheat during a game.

The Actigraph (Motionlogger) is used to determine the sleep patterns of the child during the night. The children wore these devices on four consecutive nights,first two weeknights and then two weekend nights.
scoring:
For each of the nights, the following is calculated:
- mean activity score (counts/epoch)
- median activity score (counts/epoch)
- SD of mean activity score (counts/epoch)
- total minutes scored as awake (counts/epoch)
- percentage minutes scored as sleep (100*(sleep/duration))
- sleep efficiency (100*sleep minutes/0-0 duration)
- sleep onset latency
- wake after sleep onset
- acceleration index change
- activity index percent epochs with >0 activity score
- sleep fragmentation index (# of awakenings/total sleep time in minutes * 100)
- brief wake ratio (# of awakenings <= 1 minute/total wakes)
- short burst inactivity index (# zero activity of 1 min duration/# zero activity of any duration)
- wake episodes (# of blocks of contiguous wake epochs) 
- mean duration of wake episodes in minutes
- long wake episodes (>= 5 minutes)
- duration of longest wake episode
- sleep episodes (# of blocks of contiguous sleep epochs)
- mean duration of sleep episodes in minutes
- long sleep episodes (>= 5 minutes)
- duration of longest sleep episode
- start time oo-interval
- end time oo-interval
- midpoint time oo-interval
- duration oo-interval
- start time down-interval
- end time down-interval
- midpoint down oo-interval
- duration down-interval
instruction:
To collect more information about your children's sleeping patterns, they wear an activity tracker for four nights. This is a device that looks like a watch that can register when your child is asleep or awake based on movement. Because we are interested in your children's sleeping patterns, the activity monitor only needs to be worn by your children at night.

Every evening the app indicates that the activity tracker needs to be attached to your children and every morning they can be put away again. You will be asked to put the activity tracker on your children for 4 nights. The first time will be the night before the first measurement day (for example, if you are taking measurements from Thursday to Sunday, you will be asked to put on the activity tracker for the first time on Wednesday evening, and for the last time on Saturday evening).

Put on the activity tracker in the evening before going to sleep. It is best to put the activity tracker on 5 minutes before your children go to bed. The tracker is already fully set up. You don't need to turn it on before putting it on your kids.

description: The Sleep Routines Questionnaire consists of 21 items that assess the sleep routine of the children (e.g.,at what time do the children go to bed,how long do they sleep,etc.).
The Social Contact Questionnaire consists of 10 items that assess the duration,types and importance of the children's social contacts.

The Social Emotional Questionnaire (SEQ; Sociaal Emotionele Vragenlijst [SEV]) consists of 72 items and 10 subscales that assess social-emotional problems of the child. Within L-CID,all items and subscales are used.
reference: Scholte, E.M., & Ploeg, J.D. Van der (2007). Handleiding Sociaal Emotionele Vragenlijst (SEV). Houten: Bohn Stafleu Van Loghum

description: The Social Emotional Vignettes questionnaire (SEV; original name: Brief Shame and Guilt Questionnaire) consists of 12 items and 2 subscales (Shame and Guilt) that assess feelings of shame and guilt in imaginary situations. Within L-CID,all items and subscales are used.

The Social Media Questionnaire parent report consists of 42 items,with A,B,C,and D subscales,that measure social media use,rules and attitudes of the children. The child report consists of 35 items,with A,B,and C subscales,about social media use,rules and attitudes of the children.

The Social Network Aggression Task (SNAT) is aimed to measure behavioral aggression following negative social feedback by giving the child an opportunity to respond aggressively in response to different types of peers. Prior to the lab visit, participants filled out a personal profile with questions about their favorite food or sports. During the lab visit, participants were told that unknown, same-aged peers had judged their profile and had provided feedback on whether they liked their profile (positive feedback), disliked their profile (negative feedback) or did not know whether they liked it or not (neutral feedback). Next, in the MRI scanner, participants were presented with pictures of these peers in either a green thumb up (positive feedback), a red thumb down (negative feedback) or a gray circle (neutral feedback). Following this feedback, participants had to imagine they could send a noise blast to the peer that judged them by pressing a button. The noise blast would increase in sound as they continued to press the button for a longer duration. Participants were instructed to always press the button, but to choose the duration of the button press themselves. The SNAT consisted of 60 trials: three blocks of 20 trials, with 20 trials in total for each feedback condition (positive, negative, and neutral).
scoring: A mean noise blast duration and reaction time was computed per feedback condition (positive, neutral, negative; male peers, female peers).
instruction:
We showed  your Samen Uniek profile to other children, and they gave their opinion about your profile. When you see the thumbs up, it means the other child liked your profile! I think they also like [favorite food child] and [favorite movie child]! When you see a circle, the child didn't really know what they thought about your profile. Maybe they don't like [favorite food child] but they do like [ favorite sport child]. When you see the thumbs down, the child didn't like your profile. Maybe they don't like [favorite subject child] and [favorite movie child]. 

[sound gets played] How annoying did you find this sound?

[During the practice round]: Oh, this child didn't like/liked/didn't know what to think about your profile. Now you get to decide how long you want them to listen to the sound. You have to press as quickly as possible as soon as you see the soundbar, and you only let go when the stripe on the bar reaches the volume/color you want the other child to listen to.

[Before actual task:]  As soon as you see the noise screen, you have to press the 1 with your index finger.Always press as quickly as possible, you can choose how long you want to keep the button pressed. Try to sit very still during the game.

long_name: Social Network Aggression Task (SNAT) - Early Childhood
description: The Social Network Aggression Task (SNAT) - Early Chilhood is an age-appropriate version of the Social Network Aggression Task. It is aimed to measure behavioral aggression following negative social feedback by giving the child an opportunity to respond aggressively in response to different types of peers.

The Social Network Aggression Task (SNAT) - Stories is a story based version of the SNAT,which measures behavioral aggression following negative social feedback by giving the child an opportunity to respond aggressively in response to different types of peers.
The Social Responsiveness Scale (SRS) consists of 65 items that assess social skills of the child. Within L-CID,18 items from the SRS-short form are used in combination with 3 other items.
reference: Constantino, J.N. (2002). Social Responsiveness Scale–Adult Version (SRS). Los Angeles, CA: Western PsychologicalServices.

description: The Social Wellbeing Questionnaire consists of 35 items that assess the social wellbeing of the child (e.g.,happiness) and has been developed based on co-creation with youth,the World Health Organization Quality of Life Scale,and the subscales Social Competence,Close Friendship,and Global Self-Worth from the Self-Perception Profile for Adolescents.
reference: Harter, S. (2012). Self-perception profile for adolescents: Manual and questionnaires. Denver, CO: Univeristy of Denver, Department of Psychology.

description: The Stop-Signal Task - Arrows is aimed to measure behavioral inhibition by having the child inhibit their reaction in response to a quickly appearing signal.
scoring: For each of the four block of the game, the percentage of correct Go's and correct No-Go's, the mean and median reaction time of the correct Go's, and the mean stop-signal delay time (ssd) and mean stop-signal reaction time (ssrt) are calculated. Additionally, a total mean score for all the aforementioned scores during the 4 blocks will be calculated.
instruction: Now we're going to play a game with arrows. During the game, an arrow keeps appearing on the screen. Every time the arrow is pointing to the right, you should press the right button with your right hand. When the arrow is pointing to the left, you should press the left button with your left hand. Sometimes a red arrow appears; in that case you should NOT press any button. Try to respond as fast as possible but also try to make as little errors as possible.

description: The Stop-Signal Task - Cars is aimed to measure behavioral inhibition by having the child inhibit their reaction in response to a quickly appearing signal.
scoring: For each of the five blocks of the game, the percentage of correct Go's and correct No-Go's, the mean and median reaction time of the correct Go's, and the mean stop-signal delay time (ssd) and mean and median stop-signal reaction time (ssrt) are calculated. Additionally, a total mean score for all the aforementioned scores during the 5 blocks will be calculated.
instruction: Now we're going to play a game with a car. In a bit you will see a road [RA shows picture of road] and a car will appear [RA shows picture of road with car]. When you see the car, touch it as fast as you can so  the car drives away. If you don't press, the car won't drive away. So, the first rule of the game is that you have to touch the car as fast as you can. But there is another rule of the game. Sometimes a sign will show up next to the car [RA shows sign], that sign means: Stop [RA raises hand], you are not allowed to drive, so you cannot touch the car to make it drive away. This rule is very difficult, so it's okay if it doesn't go perfectly every time. So, when you see the car you should touch it as fast as possible, but if the sign is next to the car  then you should not press. Shall we try it?

description: The Strength and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ) consists of 25 items that assess problems in several areas through 5 subscales: Prosocial,Hyperactivity,Conduct problems,Peer problems,Emotional problems. Within L-CID,all items and subscales are used,with the exception of the L-CID COVID wave,in which only 15 items are used.
scoring: Items are scored on a 3-point scale from 0 ("not true") to 2 ("certainly true"). The total score of each of the subscales can be calculated by summing the items of the corresponding subscale, taking into account the items that should be reverse coded. Items 7,11,14,21, and 25 are reverse coded. Additionally, the Emotional Problems and Peer Problems subscales can be combined into an Internalizing scale, and the Hyperactivity and Conduct Problems subscales can be combined into an Externalizing scale. A higher score means more psychosocial problems.
instruction:
Parent version: Please indicate for each of the statements below whether they are "not true", "somewhat true" or "definitely true" for your child. It is important that you answer all questions, even if you are not completely sure or if you find the question strange. We would like you to base your answers on the behavior of your child over the last six months.

Child version: Now you will see some statements about you and about how you interact with others. Please indicate whether the statement is true for you, even if you are not completely sure or if you find the question strange.

long_name: Temperament in Middle Childhood Questionnaire - Discomfort, Fear, Perceptual sensitivity (TMCQ-DFP)
description: The Temperament in Middle Childhood Questionaire (TMCQ) consists of 42 items that assess temperament and self-regulation through 4 subscales: Discomfort,Perceptual Sensitivity,Effortful Control and Fear.  Within L-CID,27 items are used from the Discomfort (how quickly is the child uncomfortable),Fear (how fearful is the child) and Perceptual Sensitivity (how sensitive to external stimuli is the child) subscales.
scoring: Items are scored on a 5-point scale from 1 ('extremely untrue') to 5 ('extremely true'). The subscale scores can be calculated by summing the items and dividing the score by the number of items that were filled in, ignoring items with a 'does not apply' response.
instruction: On the next pages you will find a set of statements that describe children's reactions to a number of situations. We would like you to tell us what your child's reaction is likely to be in those situations. There are of course no "correct" ways of reacting; children differ widely in their reactions, and it is these differences we are trying to learn about. Please read each statement and indicate to what extent the description applies to your child's reaction(s) within the past six months. If you cannot answer one of the items because you have never seen your child in that situation (for example, when you are asked how your child react when you sing but you never sing for them), then choose "Never seen them in this situation".

long_name: Temperament in Middle Childhood Questionnaire - Effortful control (TMCQ-EC)
description: The Temperament in Middle Childhood Questionaire (TMCQ) consists of 42 items that assess temperament and self-regulation through 4 subscales: Discomfort,Perceptual Sensitivity,Effortful Control and Fear. Within L-CID,15 items of the Effortful Control subscale,consisting of Attentional Control and Inhibitory Control,are used. Additionally,within L-CID items were alternated with 5 Wildman questions.
scoring: Items are scored on a 5-point scale from 1 ('extremely untrue') to 5 ('extremely true'). The subscale scores can be calculated by summing the items and dividing the score by the number of items that were filled in, ignoring items with a 'does not apply' response and taking into account the items that should be reverse coded, i.e., items 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 11, and 15.
instruction: On the next pages you will find a set of statements that describe children's reactions to a number of situations. We would like you to tell us what your child's reaction is likely to be in those situations. There are of course no "correct" ways of reacting; children differ widely in their reactions, and it is these differences we are trying to learn about. Please read each statement and indicate to what extent the description applies to your child's reaction(s) within the past six months. If you cannot answer one of the items because you have never seen your child in that situation (for example, when you are asked how your child react when you sing but you never sing for them), then choose "Never seen them in this situation".

long_name: The Brief Fear of Negative Evaluation Scale (BFNE)
description: The Brief Fear of Negative Evaluation Scale (BFNE)- Short Form consists of 12 items that assess the child's worries about the opinion of others.
reference: Watson, A., & Friend, E. (1969). Fear of negative evaluation. Empirical Validation and psychometric evaluation of the brief FNE scale in patients with Social anxiety disorder. NY: NY. Psychiatric Institute.

description: The Twin Social Interaction task aimed at measuring social behavior by having the twins play a game of Etch-a-Sketch together. The Etch-A-Sketch task is a cooperative learning challenge task that requires children to work together in order to succeed. The children are given one Etch-A-Sketch board and are instructed to use the board to copy a series of three designs that increase in complexity. The children must work together as one controls the left knob (draws only horizontal lines) and one controls the right knob (draws only vertical lines). The children are allowed a maximum of 5 minutes to complete each design, and participants are told that their accuracy on completing or copying the designs will be checked by the experimenter.
The Twin Social Skills or Difference Questionnaire consists of 8 (generally open) questions about the perceived differences between the twins,e.g.,in terms of social skills.

long_name: Visual Analogue Scale - Scanner related stress (VAS)
description: The Visual Analogue Scales (VAS) measures stress about going into the MRI scanner. The parent report consists of  4 questions during two timepoints (8 items in total),whereas the child report consists of 6 items spread out over 3 timepoints (2 items per timepoint).
scoring: Items were answered on a six-point scale from either 1 ("not fun at all") to 6 ("very much fun") or from 1 ("very excited") to 6 ("not excited at all").
instruction:
Child: Could you fill in how fun you think it is to enter the scanner? And how excited you are to enter the scanner?  
Parent/RA: How much fun do you think [child] thinks it is to enter the scanner and how excited do you think [child] is to enter the scanner?

description: The Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children - third version (WISC-III) is used to measure the IQ of a child. Within L-CID,the subscales Similarities and Block Patterns are used to determine verbal-,performance-,and total IQ.
reference: Weschsler, D., Golombok, S., & Rust, J. (1992). WISC-III UK Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children: UK Manual. 3rd ed. Sidcup, United Kingdom: Psychological Corporation

long_name: Wechsler Preschool and Primary Scale of Intelligence (WPPSI-III)
description: The Wechsler Preschool and Primary Scale of Intelligence - third edition (WPPSI-III) is used to assess verbal-,performance-,and total IQ of children. Within L-CID,the subtests Similarities and Picture Completion are used.
reference: Wechsler, D. (2002). WPPSI-III: Technical and interpretative manual. San Antonio, TX: The Psychological Corporation

long_name: Wildman items to screen for social desirability
description: The Wildman Questionnaire is a measure of social desirability and its items are embedded within other questionnaires. The questionnaire consists of a mix of items from the Wildman Symptom Checklist (WSC) and self-developed Wildman-inspired items. Six items from the Wildman Symptom Checklist (WSC) are embedded within the BSI, five or six self-developed Wildman-inspired items are embedded in either the CBQ,TMCQ,EATQ and either the PAQ or PS.
scoring: Wildman items in the BSI are scored on a 5-point scale from 0 ('not at all') to 4 ('extremely'). In the CBQ they are scored on a 7-point scale from 1 ('extremely untrue') to 7 ('extremely true') and in the EATQ are scored on a 5-point scale from 1 ('almost always untrue') to 5 ('almost always true'). Wildman items in the TMCQ questionnaire are scored on a 5-point scale from 1 ('extremely untrue') to 5 ('extremely true'). Additionally, Wildman items in the PS are scored on a 7-point scale from 1 ('my ears rarely or never itch') to 7 ('my ears itch'), and items in the PAQ are scored on a slider from 0 ('completely disagree') to 100 ('completely agree').
instruction:
BSI: In this part, you are asked to what extent you suffered from certain physical or emotional complaints in the last week. For each of the complaints below, please indicate to what extent you are or were bothered by it. 

EATQ: Below you can find 16 statements that people might use to describe their children/themselves.  For each statement, please indicate to what extent it is true for your child/you. There are no good or wrong answers. Please select the first answer that comes to you.

CBQ/TMCQ: On the next pages you will find a set of statements that describe children's reactions to a number of situations. We would like you to tell us what your child's reaction is likely to be in those situations. There are of course no "correct" ways of reacting; children differ widely in their reactions, and it is these differences we are trying to learn about. Please read each statement and indicate to what extent the description applies to your child's reaction(s) within the past six months. If you cannot answer one of the items because you have never seen your child in that situation (for example, when you are asked how your child react when you sing but you never sing for them), then choose "Never seen them in this situation".

PS/PAQ: At one time or another, all children misbehave or do things that could be harmful, are “wrong,” or that parents don’t like. Examples include: hitting someone, forgetting homework, having a tantrum, whining, throwing food, lying, arguing back, not picking up things, refusing to go to bed, coming home late. Parents have many different ways or styles of dealing with these types of problems. Below are items that describe some styles of parenting. For each item, fill in the bubble that best describes your style of parenting during the past two months with your child.

description: Zygosity Diagnosis Questionnaire consists of 5 main-items with sub-items and is aimed to determine zygosity of twins by asking parents about the zygosity of their twins (are they mono- or dizygotic) and to what extent they are alike physically. Missing DNA information was imputed with zygosity estimates derived from the Zygosity Diagnosis Questionnaire.
scoring:
Items are rated 0, 1, or 2 on a three-point scale. Dichotomous items are rated 0 or 1. By multiplying each coefficient with the item score and summing these products with the constant, a zygosity score is obtained for each individual pair. This zygosity score is compared with the classification score that is generated by the discriminant function analysis. In this study, the classification score is 0.4 for each individual dataset. Pairs whose zygosity score is greater than 0.4 are assigned the label monozygotic, pairs with scores below this classification are considered dizygotic.

Formule:
(X1*Y1)+(X2*Y2)+(X3*Y3)+(X4*Y4)+(X5*Y5)+Constant

If > 0.4: monozygotic
If <0.4: dyzygotic
